The 'First Council of Nicaea' (/naÉª'si:É/; /'ni:kaÉªja/) was a council of
Christian bishops convened in Nicaea in Bithynia (present-day Ä°znik in Turkey)
by the Roman Emperor Constantine I in AD 325. This first ecumenical council was
the first effort to attain consensus in the church through an assembly
representing all of Christendom. Richard Kieckhefer
(1989). "Papacy". [[Dictionary of the Middle Ages]]. ISBN 0-684-18275-
0. The very first church council is recorded in the book of Acts
chapter 15 regarding circumcision.

Its main accomplishments were settlement of the Christological issue of the
nature of God the Son and his relationship to God the Father, the construction of the first part of the Creed of Nicaea,
settling the calculation of the date of Easter, and
promulgation of early canon law.

headings: Separation of Easter computation from Jewish calendar
